articles.headline: As Congress Dithers, States Step In to Set Rules for the Internet
articles.snippet: Virginia, Florida, Arkansas and Maryland are among dozens of states that have introduced bills to curtail the power of Amazon, Google, Facebook and Twitter.
articles.abstract: Virginia, Florida, Arkansas and Maryland are among dozens of states that have introduced bills to curtail the power of Amazon, Google, Facebook and Twitter.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — News outlets in Florida may soon be able to sue Facebook and Twitter if the social media companies take down their content.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Federal Mask Retreat Sets Off Confusing Scramble for States and Cities
articles.snippet: Some governors and mayors quickly rolled back their mask mandates, while others said local restrictions would stay in place for now.
articles.abstract: Some governors and mayors quickly rolled back their mask mandates, while others said local restrictions would stay in place for now.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — Minnesota’s statewide mask mandate is over. But in Minneapolis, the state’s largest city, face coverings are still required.
articles.byline: By Edgar Sandoval, Kate Taylor and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: Israeli-Palestinian Strife Widens as Frantic Calls for Calm Go Unheeded
articles.snippet: While Israel and Hamas signaled willingness to consider a cease-fire, worries grew about further fracturing in one of the Middle East’s most intractable struggles.
articles.abstract: While Israel and Hamas signaled willingness to consider a cease-fire, worries grew about further fracturing in one of the Middle East’s most intractable struggles.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Violence between Israelis and Palestinians expanded in new directions on Friday, with deadly clashes convulsing the occupied West Bank and anti-Israeli protests erupting along Israel’s borders with two Arab neighbors.
articles.byline: By Vivian Yee

articles.headline: Secret Sharers: The Hidden Ties Between Private Spies and Journalists
articles.snippet: A booming, renegade private intelligence industry is increasingly shaping (and misshaping) the news.
articles.abstract: A booming, renegade private intelligence industry is increasingly shaping (and misshaping) the news.
articles.lead_paragraph: Some journalists are happy to knock on the doors of strangers. I was never one of them, but Christopher Steele, the ex-British spy behind the infamous Trump dossier, left me no choice.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier

articles.headline: Tensions Among Democrats Grow Over Israel as the Left Defends Palestinians
articles.snippet: Divisions within the party have burst into public view, with the party’s ascendant left viewing the Mideast conflict as a searing racial justice issue that carries echoes of U.S. politics.
articles.abstract: Divisions within the party have burst into public view, with the party’s ascendant left viewing the Mideast conflict as a searing racial justice issue that carries echoes of U.S. politics.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1988, when James Zogby, the founder of the Arab American Institute, pushed Democrats to include a mention of Palestinian sovereignty in their platform, party leaders responded with a clear warning, he recalled: “If the P-word is even in the platform, all hell will break loose.” Eager to stave off an angry confrontation at the convention, the issue was shelved without a vote.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Jennifer Medina

articles.headline: How a Genetic Trait in Black People Can Give the Police Cover
articles.snippet: Sickle cell trait has been cited in dozens of police custody deaths ruled accidental or natural, even though the condition is benign on its own, a Times investigation found.
articles.abstract: Sickle cell trait has been cited in dozens of police custody deaths ruled accidental or natural, even though the condition is benign on its own, a Times investigation found.
articles.lead_paragraph: When they carried the body of a 32-year-old Black man named Lamont Perry out of the woods in Wadesboro, N.C., there were no protests over his sudden death in police custody.
articles.byline: By Michael LaForgia and Jennifer Valentino-DeVries

articles.headline: After Years of Quiet, Israeli-Palestinian Conflict Exploded. Why Now?
articles.snippet: A little-noticed police action in Jerusalem last month was one of several incidents that led to the current crisis.
articles.abstract: A little-noticed police action in Jerusalem last month was one of several incidents that led to the current crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Twenty-seven days before the first rocket was fired from Gaza this week, a squad of Israeli police officers entered the Aqsa Mosque in Jerusalem, brushed the Palestinian attendants aside and strode across its vast limestone courtyard. Then they cut the cables to the loudspeakers that broadcast prayers to the faithful from four medieval minarets.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: What Would It Take to Vaccinate the World Against Covid?
articles.snippet: When President Biden joined a push to set aside patents for Covid shots, he entered a roiling debate over how to ensure poor countries get enough vaccine.
articles.abstract: When President Biden joined a push to set aside patents for Covid shots, he entered a roiling debate over how to ensure poor countries get enough vaccine.
articles.lead_paragraph: In delivering vaccines, pharmaceutical companies aided by monumental government investments have given humanity a miraculous shot at liberation from the worst pandemic in a century.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman, Apoorva Mandavilli, Rebecca Robbins and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

articles.headline: Jail Time and Big Fines: G.O.P. Seeks Harsh Penalties for Poll Workers
articles.snippet: Republicans seeking to restrict voting are proposing strict punishments for election officials and workers who make errors or violate the rules.
articles.abstract: Republicans seeking to restrict voting are proposing strict punishments for election officials and workers who make errors or violate the rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Texas — Anita Phillips has been an election judge in Texas for 17 years, responsible for managing a precinct in Waco, a city of roughly 135,000 people. But over the last four years, the civic duty she prized has become arduous. Harassment by partisan poll watchers has grown increasingly caustic, she has found, and helping voters is ever more treacherous amid a thicket of new rules.
articles.byline: By Nick Corasaniti

articles.headline: Mask? No Mask? New Rules Leave Americans Recalibrating, Hour by Hour
articles.snippet: The C.D.C. said fully vaccinated people could safely go most places without a mask. Not everyone was sure, or ready.
articles.abstract: The C.D.C. said fully vaccinated people could safely go most places without a mask. Not everyone was sure, or ready.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — For Americans whose bare faces had scarcely been seen in public for a year, there were suddenly options. Would they leave the mask behind for a jog? What about the coffee shop? What about the neighbor’s house? The office?
articles.byline: By Mitch Smith

articles.headline: From India, Brazil and Beyond: Pandemic Refugees at the Border
articles.snippet: Fleeing virus-devastated economies, migrants are traveling long distances to reach the United States and then walking through gaps in the border wall. The Arizona desert has become a favorite crossing point.
articles.abstract: Fleeing virus-devastated economies, migrants are traveling long distances to reach the United States and then walking through gaps in the border wall. The Arizona desert has become a favorite crossing point.
articles.lead_paragraph: YUMA, Ariz. — Standing by the hulking border wall, a U.S. Border Patrol agent watched as a car dropped off passengers at the edge of a road on the Mexican side. “Oh, no,” he muttered. “Here come some more.”
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan

articles.headline: When Fighting Erupts Between Israel and Hamas, the Question of War Crimes Follows
articles.snippet: Civilian deaths on both sides raise urgent questions about which military actions are legal, what war crimes are being committed and who, if anyone, will be held to account.
articles.abstract: Civilian deaths on both sides raise urgent questions about which military actions are legal, what war crimes are being committed and who, if anyone, will be held to account.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Israeli missile that slammed into a Palestinian apartment exacted a shocking toll: eight children and two women, killed as they celebrated a major Muslim holiday, in one of the deadliest episodes of the war between Israel and Palestinian militants that has raged for nearly a week.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh

articles.headline: Long Before Divorce, Bill Gates Had Reputation for Questionable Behavior
articles.snippet: Melinda French Gates voiced concerns about her husband’s relationship with Jeffrey Epstein and a harassment claim against his money manager. He also had an affair with an employee.
articles.abstract: Melinda French Gates voiced concerns about her husband’s relationship with Jeffrey Epstein and a harassment claim against his money manager. He also had an affair with an employee.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the time Melinda French Gates decided to end her 27-year marriage, her husband was known globally as a software pioneer, a billionaire and a leading philanthropist.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and Matthew Goldstein

articles.headline: AT&T-Discovery Deal Would Create a Media Juggernaut
articles.snippet: A merger could be announced as soon as Monday, in a deal that would offload the media business that AT&T fought to buy.
articles.abstract: A merger could be announced as soon as Monday, in a deal that would offload the media business that AT&T fought to buy.
articles.lead_paragraph: [Latest news: AT&T and Discovery announce deal.]
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee and John Koblin

articles.headline: Grief Mounts as Efforts to Ease Israel-Hamas Fight Falter
articles.snippet: The diplomatic wrangling came as at least 42 Palestinians were killed early Sunday in an airstrike in Gaza City, the deadliest episode in the recent bloodshed.
articles.abstract: The diplomatic wrangling came as at least 42 Palestinians were killed early Sunday in an airstrike in Gaza City, the deadliest episode in the recent bloodshed.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY — Diplomats and international leaders were unable Sunday to mediate a cease-fire in the latest conflict between Israel and Hamas, as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel vowed to continue the fight and the United Nations Security Council failed to agree on a joint response to the worsening bloodshed.
articles.byline: By Iyad Abuheweila and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: A Desperate India Falls Prey to Covid Scammers
articles.snippet: As the health care system fails, clandestine markets have emerged for drugs, oxygen, hospital beds and funeral services. Fake goods may be putting lives at risk.
articles.abstract: As the health care system fails, clandestine markets have emerged for drugs, oxygen, hospital beds and funeral services. Fake goods may be putting lives at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Within the world’s worst coronavirus outbreak, few treasures are more coveted than an empty oxygen canister. India’s hospitals desperately need the metal cylinders to store and transport the lifesaving gas as patients across the country gasp for breath.
articles.byline: By Hari Kumar and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: I’ll Take ‘White Supremacist Hand Gestures’ for $1,000
articles.snippet: How hundreds of “Jeopardy!” contestants talked themselves into a baseless conspiracy theory — and won’t be talked out of it.
articles.abstract: How hundreds of “Jeopardy!” contestants talked themselves into a baseless conspiracy theory — and won’t be talked out of it.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is an ironclad rule of the private Facebook group of past “Jeopardy!” contestants that nobody post about that night’s episode before 11 p.m. Eastern time, to avoid spoiling the show for West Coast viewers.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: Rural Areas Are Looking for Workers. They Need Broadband to Get Them.
articles.snippet: Rural communities have long complained about their lack of internet access. The pandemic and President Biden’s infrastructure plan are giving them hope for a solution.
articles.abstract: Rural communities have long complained about their lack of internet access. The pandemic and President Biden’s infrastructure plan are giving them hope for a solution.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a manufacturer of asphalt paving equipment, Weiler is exactly the type of company poised to benefit if the federal government increases spending on roads and bridges. But when Patrick Weiler talks about infrastructure, the issue he brings up first has next to nothing to do with his company’s core business.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman

articles.headline: A $100 Million Bet on Cross-Country Restaurant Delivery
articles.snippet: Goldbelly, an e-commerce platform for restaurant food, boomed during the pandemic. Will the trend stick?
articles.abstract: Goldbelly, an e-commerce platform for restaurant food, boomed during the pandemic. Will the trend stick?
articles.lead_paragraph: When the pandemic started last spring, Di Fara, one of New York City’s storied pizza joints, had the same question as countless restaurants nationwide: How would it make any money when customers weren’t allowed through its doors?
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: In a Deal With Discovery Hatched in Secret, AT&T Sheds Its Media Business
articles.snippet: The telecommunications giant will spin off WarnerMedia in a transaction that will combine HBO and CNN with Oprah Winfrey’s OWN and HGTV.
articles.abstract: The telecommunications giant will spin off WarnerMedia in a transaction that will combine HBO and CNN with Oprah Winfrey’s OWN and HGTV.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee and John Koblin
